speaking.w: `` Mr. Coverdale , ''
`` can I speak with you a moment ? ''
`` Mr. Coverdale ! -- Mr. Coverdale ! ''
`` If you pleased , Mr. Coverdale , ''
`` you might do me a very great favor . ''
`` Well , Coverdale , ''
`` you bid fair to make an admirable farmer ! Do n't you mean to get up to-day ? ''
`` What is the matter now ? ''
`` Yes , Mr. Coverdale , I used to sell a good many of those little purses . ''
`` Is it you , Coverdale ? ''
`` Pray do not ask me my other name , -- at least not yet , -- if you will be so kind to a forlorn creature . ''

`` That 's what she wants . Let her stay with us as long as she likes , and help in the kitchen , and take the cow-breath at milking time ; and , in a week or two , she 'll begin to look like a creature of this world . ''
`` Do not you need this ? ''
`` It is for use , not beauty , ''
`` I wish people would not fancy such odd things in me ! ''
`` What do you think of Priscilla now , Mr. Coverdale ? ''
`` I never think about it at all , ''
`` Not I ! ''
`` I do n't believe one word of what you say ! ''
`` You made me sad , for a minute , by talking about the past ; but the past never comes back again . Do we dream the same dream twice ? There is nothing else that I am afraid of . ''
`` I have something to say to you . ''
`` Are you angry with me ? ''
`` I am afraid you are angry with me ! ''
`` with many thanks to you , Mr. Hollingsworth , I will creep back to town again . ''
`` Ah , the dear little soul ! Why , she is really going to faint ! Mr. Coverdale , Mr. Coverdale , pray bring a glass of water ! ''
`` I can not think that this is true , ''
`` Is this true ? ''

`` She is the most admirable handiwork of God , in her true place and character . Her place is at man 's side . Her office , that of the sympathizer ; the unreserved , unquestioning believer ; the recognition , withheld in every other manner , but given , in pity , through woman 's heart , lest man should utterly lose faith in himself ; the echo of God 's own voice , pronouncing , ` It is well done ! ' All the separate action of woman is , and ever has been , and always shall be , false , foolish , vain , destructive of her own best and holiest qualities , void of every good effect , and productive of intolerable mischiefs ! Man is a wretch without woman ; but woman is a monster -- and , thank Heaven , an almost impossible and hitherto imaginary monster -- without man as her acknowledged principal ! As true as I had once a mother whom I loved , were there any possible prospect of woman 's taking the social stand which some of them , -- poor , miserable , abortive creatures , who only dream of such things because they have missed woman 's peculiar happiness , or because nature made them really neither man nor woman ! -- if there were a chance of their attaining the end which these petticoated monstrosities have in view , I would call upon my own sex to use its physical force , that unmistakable evidence of sovereignty , to scourge them back within their proper bounds ! But it will not be needful . The heart of time womanhood knows where its own sphere is , and never seeks to stray beyond it ! ''
`` I do not think it would help me . It is my heart , as you say , that makes me heavy ; and I know not why . Just now , I felt very happy . ''
`` I remember it , ''
`` Why do you ask me that question ? ''
`` Go on before , ''
`` It pleases me best to loiter along by myself . I do not walk so fast as you . ''
`` if you will wait till it is finished . ''
`` I never wish to go away , ''
`` Ah , no , ''
`` Priscilla is here , ''
`` Have not you learnt as much from your chamber window ? Would you like to see her ? ''
`` Priscilla ! Dear Priscilla ! ''
`` Oh , there is substance in these fingers of mine , ''
`` Why do you call me a dream ? Zenobia is much more like one than I ; she is so very , very beautiful ! And , I suppose , ''
`` everybody sees it , as I do . ''
`` Whenever they please to take me , ''
`` I am blown about like a leaf , ''
`` I do not know , ''
`` O Zenobia ! ''
`` Ah , Priscilla ! ''
`` how much is changed since then ! You kneel to a dethroned princess . You , the victorious one ! But he is waiting for you . Say what you wish , and leave me . ''
`` We are sisters ! ''
`` O Zenobia , ''
`` it is I that feel like the guilty one ! ''
`` And give him -- no , give Priscilla -- this ! ''
`` Bid her wear this for Zenobia 's sake , ''
`` A very small one answers all my purposes . ''

`` I have long wished to know you , Mr. Coverdale , and to thank you for your beautiful poetry , some of which I have learned by heart ; or rather it has stolen into my memory , without my exercising any choice or volition about the matter . Of course -- permit me to say you do not think of relinquishing an occupation in which you have done yourself so much credit . I would almost rather give you up as an associate , than that the world should lose one of its true poets ! ''
`` Is it irksome to you to hear your own verses sung ? ''
`` I am the first comer , ''

`` so I take the part of hostess for to-day , and welcome you as if to my own fireside . You shall be my guests , too , at supper . Tomorrow , if you please , we will be brethren and sisters , and begin our new life from daybreak . ''
`` Oh , we of the softer sex , ''
`` I am afraid , ''

`` we shall find some difficulty in adopting the paradisiacal system for at least a month to come . Look at that snowdrift sweeping past the window ! Are there any figs ripe , do you think ? Have the pineapples been gathered to-day ? Would you like a bread-fruit , or a cocoanut ? Shall I run out and pluck you some roses ? No , no , Mr. Coverdale ; the only flower hereabouts is the one in my hair , which I got out of a greenhouse this morning . As for the garb of Eden , ''
`` And now , ''

`` I must go and help get supper . Do you think you can be content , instead of figs , pineapples , and all the other delicacies of Adam 's supper-table , with tea and toast , and a certain modest supply of ham and tongue , which , with the instinct of a housewife , I brought hither in a basket ? And there shall be bread and milk , too , if the innocence of your taste demands it . ''
`` It really vexes me , ''

`` that Mr. Hollingsworth should be such a laggard . I should not have thought him at all the sort of person to be turned back by a puff of contrary wind , or a few snowflakes drifting into his face . ''
`` No ; only as an auditor -- auditress , I mean -- of some of his lectures , ''
`` They are , indeed , an odiously disagreeable set of mortals , ''
`` Take your places , my dear friends all , ''

`` seat yourselves without ceremony , and you shall be made happy with such tea as not many of the world 's working-people , except yourselves , will find in their cups to-night . After this one supper , you may drink buttermilk , if you please . To-night we will quaff this nectar , which , I assure you , could not be bought with gold . ''
`` Meantime , ''
`` it may serve to guide some wayfarer to a shelter . ''
`` He knocks as if he had a right to come in , ''
`` You do not quite do me justice , Mr. Hollingsworth , ''
`` Well , indeed , ''
`` this is an adventure , and well-worthy to be the first incident in our life of love and free-heartedness ! But I accept it , for the present , without further question , only , ''
`` it would be a convenience if we knew your name . ''
`` She is neither more nor less , ''
`` than a seamstress from the city ; and she has probably no more transcendental purpose than to do my miscellaneous sewing , for I suppose she will hardly expect to make my dresses . ''
`` Oh , we women judge one another by tokens that escape the obtuseness of masculine perceptions ! ''
`` What ears the girl must have ! ''
`` Sunny Glimpse , ''
`` What does he say ? ''
`` Mr. Coverdale , ''

`` I have been exposed to a great deal of eye-shot in the few years of my mixing in the world , but never , I think , to precisely such glances as you are in the habit of favoring me with . I seem to interest you very much ; and yet -- or else a woman 's instinct is for once deceived -- I can not reckon you as an admirer . What are you seeking to discover in me ? ''
`` What I find most singular in Priscilla , as her health improves , ''

`` is her wildness . Such a quiet little body as she seemed , one would not have expected that . Why , as we strolled the woods together , I could hardly keep her from scrambling up the trees , like a squirrel . She has never before known what it is to live in the free air , and so it intoxicates her as if she were sipping wine . And she thinks it such a paradise here , and all of us , particularly Mr. Hollingsworth and myself , such angels ! It is quite ridiculous , and provokes one 's malice almost , to see a creature so happy , especially a feminine creature . ''

`` or I shall think you lack the poetic insight . Did you ever see a happy woman in your life ? Of course , I do not mean a girl , like Priscilla and a thousand others , -- for they are all alike , while on the sunny side of experience , -- but a grown woman . How can she be happy , after discovering that fate has assigned her but one single event , which she must contrive to make the substance of her whole life ? A man has his choice of innumerable events . ''
`` Indeed ! ''
`` It is no sorcery of mine , ''
`` but I have seen the girl do that identical thing once or twice before . Can you imagine what is the matter with her ? ''
`` I am afraid you did not make a song today , while loading the hay-cart , ''
`` as Burns did , when he was reaping barley . ''
`` And on the whole , which of the two characters do you like best ? ''
`` Your literature , ''

`` will be the ` Farmer 's Almanac ; ' for I observe our friend Foster never gets so far as the newspaper . When you happen to sit down , at odd moments , you will fall asleep , and make nasal proclamation of the fact , as he does ; and invariably you must be jogged out of a nap , after supper , by the future Mrs. Coverdale , and persuaded to go regularly to bed . And on Sundays , when you put on a blue coat with brass buttons , you will think of nothing else to do but to go and lounge over the stone walls and rail fences , and stare at the corn growing . And you will look with a knowing eye at oxen , and will have a tendency to clamber over into pigsties , and feel of the hogs , and give a guess how much they will weigh after you shall have stuck and dressed them . Already I have noticed you begin to speak through your nose , and with a drawl . Pray , if you really did make any poetry to-day , let us hear it in that kind of utterance ! ''
`` And how is it with you ? ''
`` I can not conceive , ''
`` I can not conceive of being so continually as Mr. Coverdale is within the sphere of a strong and noble nature , without being strengthened and ennobled by its influence ! ''
`` Come hither , Priscilla , ''
`` Angry with you , child ? What a silly idea ! ''
`` Dear me , what can I say to the child ! ''
`` Well , well ; since you insist on my being angry , come to my room this moment , and let me beat you ! ''
`` She clung to me from the first , ''
`` The poor child ! ''
`` With what kind of a being am I linked ? ''
`` Nevertheless , ''
`` it will strangle me at last ! ''
`` I am getting weary of this , ''

`` Our own features , and our own figures and airs , show a little too intrusively through all the characters we assume . We have so much familiarity with one another 's realities , that we can not remove ourselves , at pleasure , into an imaginary sphere . Let us have no more pictures to-night ; but , to make you what poor amends I can , how would you like to have me trump up a wild , spectral legend , on the spur of the moment ? ''
`` No , not exactly a ghost story , ''

`` but something so nearly like it that you shall hardly tell the difference . And , Priscilla , stand you before me , where I may look at you , and get my inspiration out of your eyes . They are very deep and dreamy to-night . ''
`` How do you find yourself , my love ? ''
`` What matter of ridicule do you find in this , Miles Coverdale ? ''
`` Yes , if she were young and beautiful , ''
`` Poor child ! ''
`` Do you despise woman ? ''
`` Well , be it so , ''
`` They can be produced within a month , if necessary . ''
`` to announce in town , and at the watering-places , your purpose to deliver a course of lectures on the rights of women ? ''
`` Women possess no rights , ''
`` or , at all events , only little girls and grandmothers would have the force to exercise them . ''
`` I regret , on the whole , that you are leaving us , ''

`` and all the more , since I feel that this phase of our life is finished , and can never be lived over again . Do you know , Mr. Coverdale , that I have been several times on the point of making you my confidant , for lack of a better and wiser one ? But you are too young to be my father confessor ; and you would not thank me for treating you like one of those good little handmaidens who share the bosom secrets of a tragedy-queen . ''
`` you would be only too wise , too honest . Honesty and wisdom are such a delightful pastime , at another person 's expense ! ''
`` By no means , ''

`` especially when you have just resumed the whole series of social conventionalisms , together with that strait-bodied coat . I would as lief open my heart to a lawyer or a clergyman ! No , no , Mr. Coverdale ; if I choose a counsellor , in the present aspect of my affairs , it must be either an angel or a madman ; and I rather apprehend that the latter would be likeliest of the two to speak the fitting word . It needs a wild steersman when we voyage through chaos ! The anchor is up , -- farewell ! ''
`` Ah , Mr. Coverdale , ''
`` We must trust for intelligent sympathy to our guardian angels , if any there be , ''
`` As long as the only spectator of my poor tragedy is a young man at the window of his hotel , I must still claim the liberty to drop the curtain . ''
`` Those ideas have their time and place , ''
`` It is not so to me , ''
`` I rather imagine , ''

`` that your appreciation falls short of Mr. Hollingsworth 's just claims . Blind enthusiasm , absorption in one idea , I grant , is generally ridiculous , and must be fatal to the respectability of an ordinary man ; it requires a very high and powerful character to make it otherwise . But a great man -- as , perhaps , you do not know -- attains his normal condition only through the inspiration of one great idea . As a friend of Mr. Hollingsworth , and , at the same time , a calm observer , I must tell you that he seems to me such a man . But you are very pardonable for fancying him ridiculous . Doubtless , he is so -- to you ! There can be no truer test of the noble and heroic , in any individual , than the degree in which he possesses the faculty of distinguishing heroism from absurdity . ''

`` Do you know I have sometimes fancied it not quite safe , considering the susceptibility of her temperament , that she should be so constantly within the sphere of a man like Hollingsworth . Such tender and delicate natures , among your sex , have often , I believe , a very adequate appreciation of the heroic element in men . But then , again , I should suppose them as likely as any other women to make a reciprocal impression . Hollingsworth could hardly give his affections to a person capable of taking an independent stand , but only to one whom he might absorb into himself . He has certainly shown great tenderness for Priscilla . ''
`` What do you think of her ? ''
`` Well , say so if you like , ''
`` Why do you bring up his name at every turn ? ''
`` Oh , this stale excuse of duty ! ''
`` Mr. Coverdale , ''
`` you will perhaps excuse us . We have an engagement , and are going out . ''
`` Is not that a little more than you are entitled to inquire ? ''
`` Come , Priscilla , ''
`` it is time . Mr. Coverdale , good-evening . ''
`` I wish , while we sit over our wine , you would favor me with a few of those youthful reminiscences . ''
`` I have received a strange message , ''

`` requesting , or rather enjoining it upon me , to come hither . Rather from curiosity than any other motive , -- and because , though a woman , I have not all the timidity of one , -- I have complied . Can it be you , sir , who thus summoned me ? ''
`` Keep your wealth . You are right worthy of it . Keep it , therefore , but with one condition only . ''
`` Have you none to care for you ? ''

`` I have beheld what I wished . Now leave me . Linger not a moment longer , or I may be tempted to say what would bring a cloud over that queenly brow . Keep all your wealth , but with only this one condition : Be kind -- be no less kind than sisters are -- to my poor Priscilla ! ''
`` As free as to ourselves , ''

`` This long while past , you have been following up your game , groping for human emotions in the dark corners of the heart . Had you been here a little sooner , you might have seen them dragged into the daylight . I could even wish to have my trial over again , with you standing by to see fair play ! Do you know , Mr. Coverdale , I have been on trial for my life ? ''
`` It was too hard upon me , ''
`` Ah , this is very good ! ''
`` Ah ! do we part so ? ''
`` Well , perhaps nothing , ''
`` We shall see , ''
`` And I held it likewise , ''
`` Do you love her ? ''
`` And what is your answer now ? ''
`` Now , God be judge between us , ''

`` which of us two has most mortally offended Him ! At least , I am a woman , with every fault , it may be , that a woman ever had , -- weak , vain , unprincipled -LRB- like most of my sex ; for our virtues , when we have any , are merely impulsive and intuitive -RRB- , passionate , too , and pursuing my foolish and unattainable ends by indirect and cunning , though absurdly chosen means , as an hereditary bond-slave must ; false , moreover , to the whole circle of good , in my reckless truth to the little good I saw before me , -- but still a woman ! A creature whom only a little change of earthly fortune , a little kinder smile of Him who sent me hither , and one true heart to encourage and direct me , might have made all that a woman can be ! But how is it with you ? Are you a man ? No ; but a monster ! A cold , heartless , self-beginning and self-ending piece of mechanism ! ''
`` It is all self ! ''
`` Be silent ! ''
`` True , we are sisters ! ''
`` No , no , poor little thing ! ''
`` That was well said ! ''
`` Is it you , Miles Coverdale ? ''
`` It is genuine tragedy , is it not ? ''
`` Oh , a very old one will serve the purpose , ''
`` Do him no wrong , ''
`` Very little , ''
`` True , -- what is it ? ''

`` After all , I hardly know . On better consideration , I have no message . Tell him , -- tell him something pretty and pathetic , that will come nicely and sweetly into your ballad , -- anything you please , so it be tender and submissive enough . Tell him he has murdered me ! Tell him that I 'll haunt him ! ''

`` She is a pretty little creature , and will make as soft and gentle a wife as the veriest Bluebeard could desire . Pity that she must fade so soon ! These delicate and puny maidens always do . Ten years hence , let Hollingsworth look at my face and Priscilla 's , and then choose betwixt them . Or , if he pleases , let him do it now . ''
`` It is an endless pity , ''

`` that I had not bethought myself of winning your heart , Mr. Coverdale , instead of Hollingsworth 's . I think I should have succeeded , and many women would have deemed you the worthier conquest of the two . You are certainly much the handsomest man . But there is a fate in these things . And beauty , in a man , has been of little account with me since my earliest girlhood , when , for once , it turned my head . Now , farewell ! ''
`` No matter where , ''
`` The extremities die first , they say , ''

`` And so you kiss this poor , despised , rejected hand ! Well , my dear friend , I thank you . You have reserved your homage for the fallen . Lip of man will never touch my hand again . I intend to become a Catholic , for the sake of going into a nunnery . When you next hear of Zenobia , her face will be behind the black veil ; so look your last at it now , -- for all is over . Once more , farewell ! ''

`` Pray God he never has , and never may . Slow work this , however ! I should really be glad to find something ! Pshaw ! What a notion that is , when the only good luck would be to paddle , and drift , and poke , and grope , hereabouts , till morning , and have our labor for our pains ! For my part , I should n't wonder if the creature had only lost her shoe in the mud , and saved her soul alive , after all . My stars ! how she will laugh at us , to-morrow morning ! ''
`` Tell him he has murdered me ! Tell him that I 'll haunt him ! ''
`` There 's a kid shoe that never was made on a Yankee last , ''

`` I know enough of shoemaker 's craft to tell that . French manufacture ; and see what a high instep ! and how evenly she trod in it ! There never was a woman that stept handsomer in her shoes than Zenobia did . Here , ''
`` Behold ! here is a woman ! ''
`` Sluggish hospitality this ! ''
`` Who ? Really , I do n't know , ''
`` Well , well , ''
`` We 'll make it right . ''
`` Is she crazy ? Has she no tongue ? ''
`` No wonder if the poor child 's tongue is frozen in her mouth , ''
`` The very heart will be frozen in her bosom , unless you women can warm it , among you , with the warmth that ought to be in your own ! ''
`` Have you anything to ask of this lady ? ''
`` Let us not pry further into her secrets , ''
`` An old man brought her to my lodgings , ''
`` and begged me to convey her to Blithedale , where -- so I understood him -- she had friends ; and this is positively all I know about the matter . ''
`` No , no ! ''
`` If you are really sick , we must take care of you . ''
`` You are not going to die , this time , ''
`` Have you nothing to do in life , ''
`` that you fancy yourself so ready to leave it ? ''
`` And by which of my qualities , ''
`` can you suppose me fitted for this awful ministry ? ''
`` And you call me tender ! ''
`` Nothing that has an atom of sense in it , ''
`` Why did not the Frenchman make punch of it at once ? ''
`` Let me hear no more of it ! ''
`` Take the book out of my sight , ''

`` or , I tell you fairly , I shall fling it in the fire ! And as for Fourier , let him make a Paradise , if he can , of Gehenna , where , as I conscientiously believe , he is floundering at this moment ! ''
`` bellowing for the least drop of his beloved limonade a cedre ! ''
`` I will at least wait awhile , ''
`` Coverdale has given up making verses now , ''
`` I have always been in earnest , ''
`` Priscilla , Priscilla ! ''
`` you had better not run any more to-night . You will weary yourself too much . And do not sit down out of doors , for there is a heavy dew beginning to fall . ''
`` No , no , Priscilla ! ''
`` But I offer my edifice as a spectacle to the world , ''
`` that it may take example and build many another like it . Therefore , I mean to set it on the open hillside . ''

`` that is , I have met him a hundred times in town , and have often amused my fancy with wondering what he was before he came to be what he is . He haunts restaurants and such places , and has an odd way of lurking in corners or getting behind a door whenever practicable , and holding out his hand with some little article in it which he wishes you to buy . The eye of the world seems to trouble him , although he necessarily lives so much in it . I never expected to see him in an open field . ''
`` Have you learned anything of his history ? ''
`` Good-morning , Mr. Moodie , ''
`` Why do you trouble him with needless questions , Coverdale ? ''
`` Just as happy as a bird , ''
`` You shall do no such thing , Mr. Moodie , ''
`` Well , ''
`` I have not the remotest suspicion what you mean , Mr. Moodie , ''
`` nobody , to my knowledge , has called for Priscilla , except yourself . But come ; we are losing time , and I have several things to say to you by the way . ''
`` The old man , for years past , ''
`` has been a little out of his right mind , as you probably see . ''
`` Very kind , ''
`` Like an elder and younger sister , rather , ''
`` Come along , ''
`` and perhaps you may . ''
`` It shall not always be so ! ''
`` No , Priscilla ! ''
`` Despise her ? No ! ''
`` I love you , Hollingsworth ! ''
`` You seem , ''
`` to be trying how much nonsense you can pour out in a breath . ''
`` A pretty occasion for martyrdom , truly ! ''
`` That is to say , ''

`` you will die like a heathen , as you certainly live like one . But , listen to me , Coverdale . Your fantastic anticipations make me discern all the more forcibly what a wretched , unsubstantial scheme is this , on which we have wasted a precious summer of our lives . Do you seriously imagine that any such realities as you , and many others here , have dreamed of , will ever be brought to pass ? ''
`` You only half believe what you say , ''

`` and as for me , I neither have faith in your dream , nor would care the value of this pebble for its realization , were that possible . And what more do you want of it ? It has given you a theme for poetry . Let that content you . But now I ask you to be , at last , a man of sobriety and earnestness , and aid me in an enterprise which is worth all our strength , and the strength of a thousand mightier than we . ''
`` I have the funds -- as much , at least , as is needed for a commencement -- at command , ''
`` Then let it rest wholly upon mine ! ''
`` It does not suit me , ''
`` She is , ''
`` Through no base methods , as you seem to suspect , ''
`` but by addressing whatever is best and noblest in her . ''
`` What is to become of Priscilla ? ''
`` Why do you bring in the names of these women ? ''
`` Be with me , ''
`` or be against me ! There is no third choice for you . ''
`` Well ! ''
`` Zenobia , when I last saw her , ''
`` was at Blithedale . ''
`` What have you done with Priscilla ? ''
`` Come , ''
`` This place is free to you , ''

`` that judge , jury , and accuser should all be comprehended in one man ! I demur , as I think the lawyers say , to the jurisdiction . But let the learned Judge Coverdale seat himself on the top of the rock , and you and me stand at its base , side by side , pleading our cause before him ! There might , at least , be two criminals instead of one . ''
`` You forced this on me , ''
`` And why not ? ''
`` I have no concealments , ''
`` On that point , ''
`` I have had the opinion which the world holds . ''
`` You certainly spoke of none , ''
`` Had you asked me that question a short time since , ''
`` I do love her ! ''
`` With what , then , do you charge me ! ''
`` This is a woman 's view , ''
`` a woman 's , whose whole sphere of action is in the heart , and who can conceive of no higher nor wider one ! ''
`` Priscilla , ''
`` come . ''
`` Again , what is the matter ? ''
`` nor did I expect it . ''
`` would you like to keep the shoe ? ''
`` close by her heart , too ! ''
`` No , nor begun , ''
`` Not one , ''
`` it is my intention to go to Blithedale to-morrow . Can I be of any service to you before my departure ? ''
`` Ah , sir , ''

`` I do n't quite like to do that ; and , on further thoughts , Mr. Coverdale , perhaps I had better apply to some older gentleman , or to some lady , if you would have the kindness to make me known to one , who may happen to be going to Blithedale . You are a young man , sir ! ''
`` Please to excuse me to-night , Mr. Coverdale , ''

`` You are very kind ; but I am afraid I have troubled you , when , after all , there may be no need . Perhaps , with your good leave , I will come to your lodgings to-morrow morning , before you set out for Blithedale . I wish you a good-night , sir , and beg pardon for stopping you . ''
`` Gentlemen have often asked me that , ''

`` but I shake my head , and say little or nothing , and creep out of the way as well as I can . I am a man of few words ; and if gentlemen were to be told one thing , they would be very apt , I suppose , to ask me another . But it happens just now , Mr. Coverdale , that you can tell me more about the maker of those little purses than I can tell you . ''
`` Has my pale little girl a bloom ? ''
`` Has there been any call for Priscilla ? ''
`` And , Mr. Hollingsworth ! ''
`` What I would inquire , ''
`` is whether this beautiful lady is kind to my poor Priscilla . ''
`` Does she love her ? ''
`` it would gladden my old heart to witness that . If one thing would make me happier than another , Mr. Hollingsworth , it would be to see that beautiful lady holding my little girl by the hand . ''
`` With pleasure , ''
`` You can not suppose , sir , ''
`` that a poor old fellow like me knows any difference in wines . ''
`` How should that have been , Mr. Coverdale ? ''
`` The flavor of this wine , ''
`` and its perfume still more than its taste , makes me remember that I was once a young man . ''

`` they might interest you more than you suppose . But I had better be silent , Mr. Coverdale . If this good wine , -- though claret , I suppose , is not apt to play such a trick , -- but if it should make my tongue run too freely , I could never look you in the face again . ''
`` Come in ! ''
`` It was , ''
`` It is well , ''
`` Why not fling the girl off , ''
`` and let her go ? ''
`` At all events , it does not suit me to tell you . ''
`` Possibly , ''
`` Priscilla sees in me an older friend than either Mr. Coverdale or Mr. Hollingsworth . I shall willingly leave the matter at her option . ''
`` You mistake the matter completely , ''
`` Her heart ! ''

`` She is now beyond my reach . Had she lived , and hearkened to my counsels , we might have served each other well . But there Zenobia lies in yonder pit , with the dull earth over her . Twenty years of a brilliant lifetime thrown away for a mere woman 's whim ! ''
`` Pshaw ! ''

`` her brother is no such fool ! Nobody , unless his brain be as full of bubbles as this wine , can seriously think of crediting that ridiculous rumor . Why , if my senses did not play me false -LRB- which never was the case yet -RRB- , I affirm that I saw that very lady , last evening , at the exhibition , while this veiled phenomenon was playing off her juggling tricks ! What can you say to that ? ''
`` The Veiled Lady is quite up to such a thing . ''
`` I offer any wager you like , ''
`` that this very evening I find out the mystery of the Veiled Lady ! ''
`` Come forth , Theodore ! ''
`` Mysterious creature , ''
`` I would know who and what you are ! ''
`` At whatever risk , I must discover it , ''
`` there is no way save to lift my veil . ''
`` And what is that ? ''
`` Excuse me , fair lady , ''
`` if I prefer to lift the veil first ; and for this affair of the kiss , we may decide upon it afterwards . ''

`` True , my brother 's wealth -- he dying intestate -- is legally my own . I know it ; yet of my own choice , I live a beggar , and go meanly clad , and hide myself behind a forgotten ignominy . Looks this like ostentation ? Ah ! but in Zenobia I live again ! Beholding her , so beautiful , -- so fit to be adorned with all imaginable splendor of outward state , -- the cursed vanity , which , half a lifetime since , dropt off like tatters of once gaudy apparel from my debased and ruined person , is all renewed for her sake . Were I to reappear , my shame would go with me from darkness into daylight . Zenobia has the splendor , and not the shame . Let the world admire her , and be dazzled by her , the brilliant child of my prosperity ! It is Fauntleroy that still shines through her ! ''
`` Well , folks , ''
`` you 'll be wishing yourselves back to town again , if this weather holds . ''
`` We shall never make any hand at market gardening , ''

`` unless the women folks will undertake to do all the weeding . We have n't team enough for that and the regular farm-work , reckoning three of your city folks as worth one common field-hand . No , no ; I tell you , we should have to get up a little too early in the morning , to compete with the market gardeners round Boston . ''
`` The blaze of that brushwood will only last a minute or two longer , ''
`` Give the girl a hot cup of tea and a thick slice of this first-rate bacon , ''
`` something of a dab ''
`` Take my advice , brother farmers , ''
`` and get to bed as soon as you can . I shall sound the horn at daybreak ; and we 've got the cattle to fodder , and nine cows to milk , and a dozen other things to do , before breakfast . ''
`` You look like it ! ''
`` Die in a ditch ! ''
`` You must come back in season to eat part of a spare-rib , ''
`` Well , folks , what are ye about here ? ''
`` Well , boys , ''
`` what is to pay now ? ''
`` What on earth should the young woman do that for ? ''
`` Well , well , ''

`` just as you say . We 'll take the long pole , with the hook at the end , that serves to get the bucket out of the draw-well when the rope is broken . With that , and a couple of long-handled hay-rakes , I 'll answer for finding her , if she 's anywhere to be found . Strange enough ! Zenobia drown herself ! No , no ; I do n't believe it . She had too much sense , and too much means , and enjoyed life a great deal too well . ''
`` It puts me in mind of my young days , ''

`` when I used to steal out of bed to go bobbing for hornpouts and eels . Heigh-ho ! -- well , life and death together make sad work for us all ! Then I was a boy , bobbing for fish ; and now I am getting to be an old fellow , and here I be , groping for a dead body ! I tell you what , lads ; if I thought anything had really happened to Zenobia , I should feel kind o ' sorrowful . ''
`` Well , Miles Coverdale , ''
`` you are the helmsman . How do you mean to manage this business ? ''
`` Come , then , ''
`` but I doubt whether I can touch bottom with this hay-rake , if it 's as deep as you say . Mr. Hollingsworth , I think you 'll be the lucky man to-night , such luck as it is . ''
`` That looked ugly ! ''
`` Poor child ! ''
